Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation2: A serious conflict with teammates is threatening the mentee’s deliverable timeline.
Story: I stared at my phone, thumb hovering over the screen. My stepdad had texted me twice already this weekend, asking how I was doing and if I wanted to come over for dinner. I knew he wanted me to check in more often, to show I cared about being part of the family. But my mind kept drifting back to the email from my mentor, waiting for my update. The project at work was falling apart—my teammates were arguing, and deadlines were slipping. My mentor expected me to be open about problems, to reach out as soon as things got tough. I felt pulled in two directions: if I texted my stepdad, I’d be ignoring the mounting pressure at work; if I emailed my mentor, I’d be letting my family down again. My chest tightened as I scrolled between the two conversations, wishing I could be in two places at once, wishing I didn’t have to choose who to disappoint.
